articles.headline: Amazon Backtracks From Demand That Employees Delete TikTok
articles.snippet: TikTok, owned by the Chinese company ByteDance, has been under scrutiny as a potential national security threat.
articles.abstract: TikTok, owned by the Chinese company ByteDance, has been under scrutiny as a potential national security threat.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon on Friday asked its employees to delete the Chinese-owned video app TikTok from their cellphones, putting the tech giant at the center of growing suspicion and paranoia about the app.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Karen Weise

articles.headline: Facebook Said to Consider Banning Political Ads
articles.snippet: The social network has been under intense pressure for allowing misinformation and hate speech to spread on its site.
articles.abstract: The social network has been under intense pressure for allowing misinformation and hate speech to spread on its site.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook is considering banning political advertising across its network before the November general election, according to two people with knowledge of the discussions, after facing intense pressure for allowing hate speech and misinformation to flourish across its site.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: As a Flag Comes Down, Looking for a ‘New Mississippi’
articles.snippet: Much of Mississippi galvanized around the effort to remove the state flag. Residents now want to seize on the momentum created by the triumph.
articles.abstract: Much of Mississippi galvanized around the effort to remove the state flag. Residents now want to seize on the momentum created by the triumph.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Please sign up here to have the Race/Related newsletter delivered weekly to your inbox.]

articles.headline: Trump Commutes Sentence of Roger Stone in Case He Long Denounced
articles.snippet: The president’s friend had been convicted of impeding a congressional inquiry that threatened Mr. Trump.
articles.abstract: The president’s friend had been convicted of impeding a congressional inquiry that threatened Mr. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump commuted the sentence of his longtime friend Roger J. Stone Jr. on seven felony crimes on Friday, using the power of his office to spare a former campaign adviser days before Mr. Stone was to report to a federal prison to serve a 40-month term.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Maggie Haberman and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: 10 Steps to Take to Try to Prevent Your Own Eviction
articles.snippet: Some federal relief is about to expire. Local assistance is spotty. Congress may not act quickly. Here’s how to get help, or help yourself.
articles.abstract: Some federal relief is about to expire. Local assistance is spotty. Congress may not act quickly. Here’s how to get help, or help yourself.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you have a mortgage and can’t afford to pay it because of fallout from the coronavirus, you may be able to push off your payments for several months, or even into next year. But if you’re struggling to pay your rent, your options are probably much more limited.

articles.headline: Georgia. Ohio. Texas. Democrats Tell Biden to Go Big (He’s Being Cautious).
articles.snippet: This election, some Democrats argue, offers the party the provocative possibility of a new path to the presidency, even as others warn against overconfidence.
articles.abstract: This election, some Democrats argue, offers the party the provocative possibility of a new path to the presidency, even as others warn against overconfidence.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2020 election between Joe Biden and President Trump.

articles.headline: In Latin America, the Pandemic Threatens Equality Like Never Before
articles.snippet: Over the past two decades, inequality in Latin America had fallen to the lowest point in its recorded history. The pandemic threatens to reverse that. We traveled 1,000 miles across Colombia to document this critical moment.
articles.abstract: Over the past two decades, inequality in Latin America had fallen to the lowest point in its recorded history. The pandemic threatens to reverse that. We traveled 1,000 miles across Colombia to document this critical moment.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Sandra Abello grew up poor, left school at 11 and spent her teenage years scrubbing floors as a live-in maid. But by this year, something remarkable had happened.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz, Sofía Villamil and Federico Rios

articles.headline: Disney World Opens Its Gates, With Virus Numbers Rising
articles.snippet: Thousands of giddy visitors streamed into the Florida resort, as Disney tried to prove it can safely operate at a highly dangerous time.
articles.abstract: Thousands of giddy visitors streamed into the Florida resort, as Disney tried to prove it can safely operate at a highly dangerous time.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — The Bibbidi Bobbidi Boutique, a Magic Kingdom hair salon where little girls get styled like Disney princesses, remained closed this weekend. Buzz Lightyear was only able to wave from a distance. Parades and fireworks? Scratched.

articles.headline: Trump’s Clemency Came After Displays of Loyalty by Stone
articles.snippet: The extraordinary decision to commute the prison sentence of an embattled adviser demonstrates how the president has managed to bend America’s legal machinery to his advantage.
articles.abstract: The extraordinary decision to commute the prison sentence of an embattled adviser demonstrates how the president has managed to bend America’s legal machinery to his advantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Months before F.B.I. agents arrived in darkness at his Florida home to take him into custody, Roger J. Stone Jr. promised that he would remain loyal to his longtime friend. “I will never roll on Donald Trump,” he said.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Chatham Hedge Fund Has the Winning Bid for McClatchy Newspapers
articles.snippet: The family-owned publisher of The Sacramento Bee and The Miami Herald announced the winner of its bankruptcy sale: Chatham Asset Management, the owner of The National Enquirer.
articles.abstract: The family-owned publisher of The Sacramento Bee and The Miami Herald announced the winner of its bankruptcy sale: Chatham Asset Management, the owner of The National Enquirer.
articles.lead_paragraph: After years of declines in revenue and print circulation, the McClatchy Company, one of the largest and most respected news publishers in the country, announced on Sunday that it expected to be bought by Chatham Asset Management, a New Jersey hedge fund, at the conclusion of a bankruptcy auction.

articles.headline: Ja’Ron Smith’s Balancing Act: A Black Republican Navigates the Trump White House
articles.snippet: As a congressional staff member, Mr. Smith once wore a hoodie in a demonstration on Capitol Hill protesting the death of Trayvon Martin. Now President Trump calls him “my star.”
articles.abstract: As a congressional staff member, Mr. Smith once wore a hoodie in a demonstration on Capitol Hill protesting the death of Trayvon Martin. Now President Trump calls him “my star.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the days after Trayvon Martin was shot and killed by a white neighborhood watch volunteer, Ja’Ron Smith was among a group of congressional aides who pulled on hoodies and stood on the steps of the U.S. Capitol in protest.

articles.headline: What Donald Trump’s ‘Access Hollywood’ Weekend Says About 2020
articles.snippet: On a Friday, the world heard vulgar audio of Mr. Trump boasting about forcing himself on women. By Sunday night, the episode that was supposed to doom him had begun to recede.
articles.abstract: On a Friday, the world heard vulgar audio of Mr. Trump boasting about forcing himself on women. By Sunday night, the episode that was supposed to doom him had begun to recede.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, down and unwilling to get out, saw only one way back up: Go lower.

articles.headline: While America Looks Away, Autocrats Crack Down on Digital News Sites
articles.snippet: Independent journalism is on the defensive, from Hungary to Malaysia.
articles.abstract: Independent journalism is on the defensive, from Hungary to Malaysia.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like many American media types, I spent a lot of time last week reading heated arguments about free speech. I was wondering if I, too, could count myself as a “veteran of the Twitter wars” when Steven Gan distracted me by telling me about his car.

articles.headline: Florida Breaks U.S. Coronavirus Record for Most New Cases in a Day
articles.snippet: The state recorded 15,300 new coronavirus cases on Sunday, easily passing the previous one-day high of 12,274 set at the height of the outbreak in New York in April.
articles.abstract: The state recorded 15,300 new coronavirus cases on Sunday, easily passing the previous one-day high of 12,274 set at the height of the outbreak in New York in April.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Florida on Sunday reported the highest single-day total of new coronavirus cases by any state since the start of the pandemic, with more than 15,000 new infections, eclipsing the previous high of 12,274 recorded in New York on April 4 amid the worst of its outbreak.
articles.byline: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura, Rick Rojas and Sheri Fink

articles.headline: How May Google Fight an Antitrust Case? Look at This Little-Noticed Paper
articles.snippet: A document sent by the search giant to Australian regulators argues that the company doesn’t control enough of the digital ad industry to overcharge customers or block competitors.
articles.abstract: A document sent by the search giant to Australian regulators argues that the company doesn’t control enough of the digital ad industry to overcharge customers or block competitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Google has largely stayed quiet about its conversations with federal investigators as the Justice Department has looked into whether the company abused its dominance of the online advertising market.

articles.headline: How Russia Built a Channel to the Taliban, Once an Enemy
articles.snippet: The recent assessment that Russia paid bounties to the insurgents to attack U.S. troops stunned many, but officials said the Kremlin’s outreach began almost a decade ago.
articles.abstract: The recent assessment that Russia paid bounties to the insurgents to attack U.S. troops stunned many, but officials said the Kremlin’s outreach began almost a decade ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — During one of the most violent stretches of fighting in northern Afghanistan, as the Taliban scored victories that had eluded them since the beginning of the conflict, the top American commander went public with a suspicion that had nagged for years: Russia was aiding the insurgents.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal and Michael Schwirtz

articles.headline: Inside the White House, a Gun Industry Lobbyist Delivers for His Former Patrons
articles.snippet: The Trump administration lifted a ban on sales of silencers to private overseas buyers that was intended to protect U.S. troops from ambushes. The change was championed by a lawyer for the president who had worked for a firearms trade group.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration lifted a ban on sales of silencers to private overseas buyers that was intended to protect U.S. troops from ambushes. The change was championed by a lawyer for the president who had worked for a firearms trade group.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael B. Williams spent nearly two years helping to run a trade group focused on expanding sales of firearm silencers by American manufacturers.
articles.byline: By Michael LaForgia and Kenneth P. Vogel

articles.headline: The Pandemic Has Accelerated Demands for a More Skilled Work Force
articles.snippet: Even groups that regularly disagree on labor issues said there should be significant public investment in programs that can upgrade the skills of American workers.
articles.abstract: Even groups that regularly disagree on labor issues said there should be significant public investment in programs that can upgrade the skills of American workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Economists, business leaders and labor experts have warned for years that a coming wave of automation and digital technology would upend the work force, destroying some jobs while altering how and where work is done for nearly everyone.

articles.headline: ‘I Can’t Keep Doing This:’ Small-Business Owners Are Giving Up
articles.snippet: More owners are permanently shutting their doors after new lockdown orders, realizing that there may be no end in sight to the crisis.
articles.abstract: More owners are permanently shutting their doors after new lockdown orders, realizing that there may be no end in sight to the crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the last Friday of June, after Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas said that bars across the state would have to shut down a second time because coronavirus cases were skyrocketing, Mick Larkin decided he had had enough.
